items.title: Section 80C - Deductions for Investments
items.content: Section 80C of the Income Tax Act allows deduction up to ₹1,50,000 from gross total income. Eligible investments include: EPF/VPF contributions, PPF deposits, ELSS mutual funds, Life insurance premiums, NSC, Sukanya Samriddhi Account, 5-year bank FDs, Senior Citizen Savings Scheme (SCSS), Tuition fees for children (max 2 children), Principal repayment of home loan (only principal, not interest), NPS contributions under 80CCD(1). Note: Total deduction under 80C, 80CCC, and 80CCD(1) combined cannot exceed ₹1.5 lakh.

items.title: Section 80D - Medical Insurance Premium Deduction
items.content: Section 80D allows deduction for health insurance premiums. For individuals below 60 years: ₹25,000 for self/spouse/children. For senior citizens (60+ years): ₹50,000. Additional ₹25,000 (₹50,000 for senior citizen parents) for parents' health insurance. Preventive health checkup: ₹5,000 (included within overall limit). Total maximum deduction can go up to ₹1,00,000 if both taxpayer and parents are senior citizens.

items.title: Standard Deduction for Salaried Employees - FY 2024-25
items.content: Standard deduction of ₹50,000 is available to all salaried individuals and pensioners under both old and new tax regimes for FY 2024-25 (AY 2025-26). This deduction is automatically applied and does not require any investment or expenditure. It is deducted from gross salary before calculating taxable income.

items.title: Income Tax Slabs - Old Regime FY 2024-25
items.content: Old Tax Regime for FY 2024-25: Up to ₹2,50,000 - Nil, ₹2,50,001 to ₹5,00,000 - 5%, ₹5,00,001 to ₹10,00,000 - 20%, Above ₹10,00,000 - 30%. Surcharge: 10% if income between ₹50L-₹1Cr, 15% if ₹1Cr-₹2Cr, 25% if ₹2Cr-₹5Cr, 37% above ₹5Cr. Cess: 4% on (tax + surcharge). Rebate under 87A: If total income ≤ ₹5,00,000, full tax rebate up to ₹12,500. Allows deductions under 80C, 80D, HRA, LTA, etc.

items.title: Income Tax Slabs - New Regime FY 2024-25
items.content: New Tax Regime for FY 2024-25 (Default): Up to ₹3,00,000 - Nil, ₹3,00,001 to ₹7,00,000 - 5%, ₹7,00,001 to ₹10,00,000 - 10%, ₹10,00,001 to ₹12,00,000 - 15%, ₹12,00,001 to ₹15,00,000 - 20%, Above ₹15,00,000 - 30%. Rebate under 87A: If total income ≤ ₹7,00,000, full tax rebate (effectively no tax up to ₹7L). Standard deduction of ₹50,000 is available. No other deductions like 80C, 80D, HRA allowed.

items.title: HRA Calculation Rules
items.content: House Rent Allowance (HRA) exemption is calculated as the minimum of: 1) Actual HRA received, 2) 50% of salary if living in metro cities (Mumbai, Delhi, Kolkata, Chennai), or 40% for non-metro, 3) Rent paid minus 10% of salary. Salary = Basic + DA. HRA exemption is NOT available under new tax regime. Taxpayers living in rented accommodation must choose old regime to claim HRA benefit.

items.title: ITR Form Selection Guide
items.content: ITR-1 (Sahaj): For individuals with salary/pension income, one house property, and other sources (interest) up to ₹50L total income. ITR-2: For individuals/HUFs without business income but having capital gains, multiple properties, or foreign assets. ITR-3: For individuals/HUFs with business/profession income. ITR-4 (Sugam): For presumptive income under section 44AD, 44ADA, 44AE (turnover up to ₹2 crore). ITR-5: For firms, LLPs, AOPs, BOIs. ITR-6: For companies (other than companies claiming exemption under section 11). ITR-7: For trusts, political parties, charitable institutions.
